hedline.hl1: Handicaps Are No Bar, A Medical School Says

block.p: After fighting for more than two years to get into medical school, a 23-year-old quadriplegic has been accepted by Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

When the wheelchair-bound student, James B. Post 4th, graduated last year from King's College in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., his grade-point average was 3.922 and his medical-school admission test scores were above average. But his application was rejected by 10 medical schools; he said they told him they could not accommodate a quadriplegic student.
After fighting for more than two years to get into medical school, a 23-year-old quadriplegic has been accepted by Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

When the wheelchair-bound student, James B. Post 4th, graduated last year from King's College in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., his grade-point average was 3.922 and his medical-school admission test scores were above average. But his application was rejected by 10 medical schools; he said they told him they could not accommodate a quadriplegic student.

In January, Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania signed a measure, nicknamed the Jimmy Post Bill, barring such discrimination. But this year Mr. Post was again rejected by 15 schools. The acceptance from Einstein arrived last week.
"I got what I wanted," he said in an interview. "I didn't have to sue a school to get in."
